comments.commentBody:
Davis Gottfried, you say, "...if you are very rich, you are deemed to be intrinsically morally and intellectually superior."

I think that may be only in the United States, the place where many people get their education from TV. If it's on TV it must be true and all those well dressed people on the tube must be smart. TV is the medium that, well not a certain bridge in Brooklyn, but it can sell anything to the dolts who tune in.

Oh, yeah, we are in big trouble. Trump is the king of the boop-tube and the boops are voting.
Maybe Trump's foreign policy advisors are his wife and those beautiful contestants from Miss Universe!

Gail Collins correctly reported that Trump said that his most important foreign policy adviser was himself. He presumably talks to himself when he seeks edification on international affairs.

He is patently as mad as a hatter. As we all know, his narcissism knows no bounds. In many circumstances a man with such an aberrant conception of himself and the world would be deposited in an institution. However, this man is lauded and adored by the media and he is well on his way toward capturing a party which once nominated Abraham Lincoln.
Why does he fare so well. Because he is filthy rich. And what does this prove? This proves that Capitalism is often a grotesque system because it posits a perfect correlation between monetary wealth and inherent worth, i.e., if you are very rich, you are deemed to be intrinsically morally and intellectually superior. Actually, Harvard proved the falsity of Capitalism's assumption that great wealth was indicative of inherent superiority. IN 1968, that school's psychology department found that the variable that correlated most strongly with financial wealth was the ability to look someone in the eye and lie at the same time. That, my friend, is the art of the deal.
Feel the Bern.

Amanda Cohen, how dare you say my darling cauliflower is bland! I recently decided that my childhood had too little cauliflower and I can now make up for that. When I was growing up cauliflower must have been more expensive than cabbage, zucchini, or (gag) succotash, so I rarely got it. While raising our own children we've eaten megatons of broccoli since my daughter decided it was da bomb. But she has since moved out and eats her own broccoli at least once a day. It is my time  to enjoy a paler, tastier cruciferous vegie. If others find it to be bland, I say, "Tough, that leaves more for me!"
I didn't read "fat is bad" anywhere in the article, m. I believe Melissa was concerned with the time and mess that frying involves.

I think the larger issue here is the mess and inconvenience of frying. I requires much more attention than simply prepping the food and putting it in the oven and makes a far greater mess than oven baking. Additionally it can stink up the house and is a much bigger mess to clean up. I rarely fry anything at home and certainly not on a weeknight. This is a recipe I would easily tackle during the week though.

The recipe didn't call for a deep fryer so your tempest is misplaced. Comments in recipes are a strange place for your crusade. Better to suggest omitting the flour and panko if worried about carb/sugars. No tartar sauce us listed either so what us all this crying about?

"minus the fryer"

Again the Times won't listen to it's own reporting about fat in general. Home cooks will be using canola, better if they use peanut, better if it is organic, but they will not be using commercial deep fryer fat (like McDonalds, etc.). So no, the fat here is absolutely NOT the problem, but rather the worse thing in the recipe is the panko bread crumbs and whatever flour gets used and however much sugar is in the tartar sauce. But, that said, fry up you fish: the flour panko and sugar is not all that much compared other common dietary foodstuffs in terms of making people overweight and messing with their blood sugar.

But seriously, It's really waaaay past time that the Times stops adhering to the "fat is bad" mantra and passes along the memo to all the food-section staff.
Count me as one more Yale alumnus who only recently learned of the team's entry into the tournament, and who is very charmed, indeed. Well done, gentlemen. Boola! Boola!

Come on Yalies at least comment on this article, geez!  Get with the spirit please!  This UConn fan would like nothing better than a Yale victory over Duke!  Go Bulldogs!  FYI that's your schools nickname

As a Yale class of '71 graduate, who also never followed our basketball team--that was the era of Yale football excellence, with the likes of Calvin Hill (father or NBA star Grant Hill) and Brian Dowling (later "B.D." in Doonesbury by Yalie Gary Trudeau)--it's fun to cheer on this group of tall and buff Elis. Fwiw, it also made me recall a factoid that I'd forgotten: Duke was my "safety" school. May the best team win.

WHY is this in the "Sports" section? What utterly fatuous fluff! The idea seems to wave in shout-outs to a bizarre group of Yalies (perhaps the writer's buds?) instead of saying anything of interest.

How about writing about SPORTS and leaving this filler in the "Styles" Section?

"Insufferable"? Why? Because both of these school maintain academic standards for players and expect them to attend class, do their own work, take their own exams and graduate with real degrees?

The USAToday writer admits his loathing is driven by simply jealousy, then does on to spew a bunch of cliches about how every Duke or Yale grad makes huge amounts of money, is selfish, elitist and entitled.

This Dukie does not "make so much money it would make me physically sick if I saw your bank account" - in fact, a Duke magna cum laude degree is no proof against being laid off during the recession and then falling victim to age discrimination. I am revolted by Duke's recent spending and elasticity of the rules in pursuit of football prowess and think the fetishization of the hoops team is stupid and crass. However, the resentment and "hatred" toward students who can perform at high levels both academically and athletically, and the anger at schools that demand that they do so, is ugly and destructive.

The only thing 'insufferable' about the prospect of a Duke-Yale match up is that a pairing of such true student-athletes happens so very infrequently.
That author of that article is a Tulane alumnus, writing as if Tulane were not in the same safety school league as Duke.

Good article. I liked the quotes, especially “We became very intense fans, cheering every free throw Yale made, even though I could not name a single player on the team.”

But we've all jumped on a bandwagon at some point or another, yes? I admit I liked another perspective at USA Today, which I found quite accurate - "Duke-Yale is the most insufferable college basketball game imaginable"

http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/03/duke-yale-is-the-most-insufferable-colle...

"...we’re left with the choice of rooting for one of these teams. It’s a nightmare. I can’t stand it. I’m going to go for a long walk during this game, admire the sunshine, and pretend basketball was never invented."
Actually in this country one is presumed innocent until proven guilty you can ask the Duke lacrosse team about that for starters

A worthy person to defend since important due process rights were denied the young man in the name of social justice.

Yale is not the state and, therefore, doesn't need to follow the Constitution's pronouncements on criminal due process. But, it should. It's Yale.
Who wouldn't be charmed by a team coming together to defend a rapist?

While I'm thrilled for the basketball team, the university and its authoritarian politically-correct culture have become an embarrassment to many reasonable alumni including myself.  I can only hope that a few members of the 2006 Duke Lacrosse team attend the game and sit in solidarity with Jack Montague.
Don't kid yourself, I'm sure the lockerroom is relieved.
We do not know if there was "no issue." Kids hanging around a baseball field with flying balls and bats and 100s of unknown employees does not seem like the ideal learning ground.
Yeah.  Must be why his teammates were going to boycott a scheduled exhibition game until Ventura pleaded with them not to.

As easy as it would appear to be to hate on Williams and side completely with LaRouche in this matter, you have to be fair and say that what Williams said makes a lot of sense. Namely, what other job do you see where a 14 yr old boy goes to work with his father EVERY DAY for the WHOLE DAY? Exactly, none. They wanted him to scale it back, and he refused to compromise. They didn't release him...he quit. I give him credit for not going all Lawyer on them and trying to sue for breach of contract. We should just chalk it up to a clash of beliefs and let it go. Now he can spend his time home-schooling 365 days a year and coach his sons teams. Everybody wins...except maybe the White Sox locker room, which seems full of dissension.

Kudos to LaRoche. However, he was in a position where he had some leverage, substantial money in the bank (I assume) and a previous oral contract likely being violated. I can't help but think of all the fathers who would like to take their kids to work, whose work would not be affected by the kid's presence, but have no leverage other than a willingness to be fired and have his kid go hungry.
I'm happy for the Laroches.  When you're dead, you are going to be dead for a VERY long time.  Enjoying your time on earth with the people you love trumps everything else--.
This could have been handled better by all the adults

Home-schooled kids usually are more socially adapted than most public school kids.  I know that seems counter-intuitive, but it's true for most home-schooled kids. Therefore, it comes as no surprise the lad was appreciated by the players.  Trust me; I work with home-schooled kids and previously taught for 25+ years in public schools.  Education and school can be two separate issues.

CKent.....

The boy "very well may be getting a better education than he'd get in a public school." Perhaps, but we don't know, since the regulation of home schooling in most states is very lax. And if the concern is specifically about public schools, consider that LaRoche should have plenty of money to put his son in a first-rate private school.

My experience over several decades as an educator is that home-schooled youth tend to lack substantive breadth - they are knowledgeable in one or two areas, but are clueless in many others - and have weak critical-thinking skills, in part because they often are philosophically rigid.
A very succinct and pointed reply to LaRoche -- well done and keep it up!

Instead of a weepy portrait of Laroche's dedication to his son, why not mention that LaRoche has said "we're not big on school" and that Drake will get a better education in the clubhouse than in class. So he's basically denying his son's human right to education.  What a joke.

It seems appalling no self-respecting republican is willing to mount the courage to say Enough Already, and not lend support to any of the two wild, and unacceptable, candidates remaining. That Trump is unpredictable, prejudiced and ignorant, and a bully (hence, a coward) is a well known fact. But Ted Cruz is the most dangerous and hated individual no one can stand, as he is a religiously- motivated dogmatic, spewing lies, and adamant at destroying the very construct of the country's democratic process. Although unpalatable, there is one way out: vote for the democratic candidate, so reason may prevail, reality recognized for what it is, so that politics may recognize 'compromise' as a necessary and welcome tool to get things done. Otherwise, all those that have condemned Trump and Cruz as bigots...and worse, and now supporting either one, may deserve, in all justice, to be called hypocrites, cowards, and lacking the power of their convictions.

If Trump arrives at the Convention with more delegates than anyone else, but less than 50% of the total, he hasn't yet won the nomination "fair and square".  If Trump fails to win an absolute majority of votes in the first ballot at the Convention, it would be perfectly fair and reasonable (and in accordance with rules that Trump has accepted by competing for the GOP nomination) for delegates to vote for and select some other candidate in a subsequent ballot.  If this were not the case, what is the point of conducting votes at the Convention?

I have always thought that The Donald's plan was to make a deal for, say, a billion $$, to bow out and support whomever the GOP controllers designated. He would have agreed to keep the terms private. Of course, after a few months (say in October) he would find some reason to publicize the deal, show himself to be a winner and the GOP to be inept chumps.
But now, I'm not so sure. He may believe that he can actually govern.
This is more fun than professional wrestling.

Much as I despise The Donald I can't honestly blame him for reading the GOP "establishment" the Riot Act.  If he does come in to the convention with many more delegates than anyone else (i.e., Cruz and Kasich) he will have done so fair and square.  If the Party leaders then turn away from him and hand the nomination to one of the others- or to Paul Ryan or Mitt Romney- they'll truly deserve to have a riot on their hands.  At the very least, the Reichsfuhrer will lead his untermenschen out the front door, establish a third party candidacy and hand the general election to Hillary (or Bernie).  Having gone this far to win over "hearts" and "minds," he's not going to do something completely out of character, like go gently into that good night.  Nor should he.

.
@ idzach

The rise of Donald Trump should drive many Americans -- certainly, our historians, philosophers, psychologists, clergy, and scholars of electoral politics -- to carefully and unblinkingly examine who we are and why we vote the way we vote. So epic is the cache of hidden traits that have been uncovered by that living, breathing, short-fingered Rohrshach Test.

But that is not a sign that he can win the 2016 presidential election. In my opinion, he cannot. Ahead of him are numerous speeches and appearances, debates, delegate-selection events, encounters with State law and rules, a party Convention, more campaigning, more debates, attacks on him by PACs, financial realities, more encounters with State law and rules, voting, election litigation, and the Electoral College process.

At one of those junctures, he will be thwarted. Either his pursuit of office will actually end (he will fail to qualify for the ballot in enough states, e.g.) or it will figuratively grind to a halt (as happened to the unqualified Marco Rubio when his adopted home state did not support him for nomination).

We have tremendous cause for worry about our nation. There are unknowns which could turn out to be immensely disturbing. But our worries need not include the chance of Donald Trump taking the Presidential Oath next January.

The two families are in the same order, which makes them relatives. It's like saying two genera in the same family are relatives or two species in the same genus are relatives.

I'm not sure what the order of families in your reference signifies, but it seems a bit out of date. For instance, Commelinaceae and Pontederiaceae have been moved to a different order, Commelinales while Cyperaceae and Juncaceae remain in Poales.

I'm not at all disappointed with this clue.
A standing ovation for this comment!

As for your comment about Mitch McConnell, it reminds me of the old Rodney Dangerfield joke.
Doctor to Mitch: You're cynical.
Mitch: I want a second opinion.
Doctor: Ok, you're ugly, too.

Now wait a minute. There are decent people among the Republicans.

Just not enough to move the party towards decency.

Even if the Republicans manage to get rid of Il Trumpe, they have no one qualified to run fo0r president of the USA.

Ted Cruz? Gov. Kasich? Mitt Romney? Paul Ryan? Extreme right-wing ideologues all.

The Republican party is a racist, classist, sexist dinosaur fit for nothing higher than the dustbin of history. The sooner it arrives there the better, starting first and foremost with their idiotic Senate leader, Mitch McConnell, the most cynical man in Washington.
I am worried about Bill tho. Lately he seems encumbered emotionally!
I thought the 1% were the Hell's Angels.  Or are they now the elite in the US?

I'd be more inclined to agree if the people also seemed to be willing to throw all the other bums out--specifically the highly overcompensated do-nothings masquerading as congresspeople.

But apparently the "they're all corrupt" mentality doesn't extend to people's individual legislators ("s/he seems nice").

Though I wish it would be, I don't think 2016 qualifies as a wave election year yet. Trump's popularity represents the sour grapes of a contingent of scared xenophobic working class conservatives--who DO have legitimate economic problems--who think that blowing a raspberry toward Washington is an effective way to register their displeasure. But these conservatives don't seem to have any decent ideas about how to fix what they deem to be broken, or how getting the rot out of Congress, and local legislatures, might be a first step; they just want the good feeling that comes with being angry and denigrating, because that's about all the pleasure they can afford these days.

(If they had any sense, and weren't so easy to lead into the divide and conquer trap set up by cynical plutocrats, they might consider voting for Bernie. But "you're getting what you don't deserve" seems to Trump--pun intended--"we're all in this together" every time.)

There's lot of funny stuff to say here, but think about what you're really saying.

The situation is that the establishment politicians have done such an abysmal job of looking out for their constituents, for decades now, that the electorate is furious and ready to "throw the bums out."

The consensus among the upper classes seems to be that it's perfectly okay for the Republican elites to take the steering wheel away from the voters when they don't like who the voters are likely to elect.

On the Democratic side, this has largely been achieved pre-emptively by the DNC and the Clinton Machine co-opting the entire main stream media. Their view was: we're picking Hillary, don't give the voters any other choice. And because of the utter failure of the Fourth Estate to do its job, and instead becoming the mouthpiece of the Clinton Campaign, they have largely succeeded in making it extremely difficult for a different candidate to get basic airtime and serious consideration.

The Repubs on the other hand, are just going to do a brazen, late-in-the-game power grab.

Given JFK's words: "Those who would make a peaceful revolution impossible, make a violent revolution inevitable", wouldn't it be wiser for the elite/establishment/1% to reconsider their game plan of seizing power in whatever undemocratic way they can, and start working for the American People instead of Wall Street and the Koch Brothers?
You forget that they all lie when they say that climate change is a hoax.
That's what the vote for Trump is, an attack on the regulars. The voters are trying to frag the officers.
And they need to blame the corporations that off-shored their jobs.

The old white male "regulars" of the GOP are not happy with the current choices of Donald, Ted, and John. For 7 plus years the GOP has voted against the ACA forever and followed Ted to close down the government and ruin American's vacations to National Parks and cost the government they hate millions. Seven years and no higher minimum wage, no additional spending on infrastructure (jobs, jobs, jobs and much needed improvements-even Donald recognizes our airports need work!), no support for women's health, no tax reduction for the middle class & lower, no help with education expenses, no support for renewable energy,  ... Nothing has been done to improve anyone's life. And this party of white men wonder why there is a fire in the party they cannot control or suffocate? Their racist attitude toward Pres. Obama has diminished their party and hurt our nation. Unfortunately, those supporting the current GOP candidates are still blaming the wrong people. Rather than attacking immigrants and Muslims and every other group they don't like, these followers need to attack the regulars of the party who have done nothing for 7 plus years.

I like that way better than a President Jeb Bush, with all the advisers and sycophants who helped to destroy the country and its economy under a President George W. Bush.

Why just 8 years ago, we hated Bush for what he did to our country. We elected Obama for the change he promised, but could not deliver.

A Change is Gonna Come...
don't let gail collins convince you that another Bush presidency would be a good thing. For her stock portfolio perhaps, but not for American lives and workers and young people.
SKJ:  Who will be his vice president?
No!  Trump has but one advisor, he himself with his great brain and the best words.

Gail, Trump is well-prepared for victory and has a tremendous group of advisers waiting in the wings after he gets elected:

Melania Trump (wife), First Lady
Donald Trump Jr. (son), White House Chief of Staff
Ivanka Trump (daughter), Secretary of State
Robert Trump (brother), Secretary of the Treasury
Maryanne Trump, (sister), Supreme Court Justice
Elizabeth Trump (sister), Secretary of Commerce
Eric Trump (son), Secretary of Labor
Tiffany Trump (daughter), White House spokeswoman
Barron Trump (son), Secretary of Agriculture. He's a preteen, but who knows or cares what a Secretary of Agriculture does? He'll be tremendous in the position. In addition to being the president, Trump will assume the roles of Attorney General, Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Transportation, and Director of Homeland Security. The Trump family will be tremendous for all of us.
The Donald is hardly a Bolshevik.  He's more like a Bolsh'ik artist.  Actually it's Il Duce who comes to mind (he was good at making silly faces, too).

It sounds like your religious views are letting you confuse the medical difference between a child and a fetus.  It also sounds like you don't understand the legal separation of church and state.   I was going to mention the fact that, in the same way I don't get to impose my belief that until you become clear about the difference, you should have a vasectomy, you don't get to dictate what a woman does with her body.
